statement.text: AAA natural history follows a predictable pattern: average growth rate is 2-3 mm/year for small aneurysms, accelerating with larger diameters. Rupture risk is size-dependent: <1% per year for AAAs <5 cm, increasing exponentially to 20-40% per year for AAAs â‰¥7 cm. The majority of AAAs are discovered incidentally and remain asymptomatic until rupture.
statement.formal: AAA Growth Rate: ~0.2-0.3 cm/year (small), ~0.4-0.5 cm/year (large) | Rupture Risk per Year: <5cm: <1%, 5-6cm: 3-15%, 6-7cm: 10-20%, >7cm: 20-40%

explanation.intuition: Imagine an AAA as a slowly inflating balloon. Small balloons need a lot of air to expand noticeably, but as the balloon gets bigger, the same amount of air causes larger expansion. Similarly, small AAAs grow slowly, but larger ones grow faster because of Laplace's law - the wall stress is greater at larger diameters. The rupture risk follows the same pattern: a small balloon can hold pressure, but as it stretches, the wall gets thinner and weaker until eventually it bursts.
explanation.key_insight: The 5.5 cm threshold for intervention in men (5.0 cm in women) represents the diameter at which the risk of rupture begins to exceed the risk of elective repair. Below this threshold, the natural history favors surveillance. Above it, the natural history favors intervention.
explanation.technical_details: Growth rate acceleration: AAAs <4 cm grow ~1-2 mm/year, 4-5 cm grow ~2-3 mm/year, >5 cm grow ~4-5 mm/year. Rupture occurs when wall stress exceeds wall strength. Wall stress increases with diameter (Laplace) while wall strength decreases (wall thinning, matrix degradation). Women have smaller aortas, so a 5 cm AAA represents relatively greater dilation. Rupture-free survival without repair: at 5 years, 50% for 5-6 cm AAAs, 20% for >6 cm. Rapid expansion (>1 cm/year) indicates unstable aneurysm requiring intervention regardless of size.
common_misconceptions: All AAAs grow at the same rate - larger ones grow faster
AAAs under 5 cm never rupture - they can, but risk is low
AAA growth is linear - it's actually exponential with size
Once stable, AAAs remain stable - growth can accelerate unpredictably

definitions_glossary.natural_history: Expected course of disease without intervention
definitions_glossary.rupture: Full-thickness tear of aneurysm wall with hemorrhage
definitions_glossary.surveillance: Regular monitoring with imaging to track changes
definitions_glossary.rapid_expansion: Growth >1.0 cm per year, indication for intervention

definition.@value: Expected progression and outcomes of untreated AAA including growth rates and rupture risk

enables.title: AAA Surgical Indications
enables.reason: Natural history determines when to intervene

sources.citation: UK Small Aneurysm Trial Participants. Mortality results for randomised controlled trial of early elective surgery or ultrasonographic surveillance for small abdominal aortic aneurysms. Lancet. 1998;352:1649-1655.
Lederle FA, et al. Rupture rate of large abdominal aortic aneurysms in patients refusing or unfit for elective repair. JAMA. 2002;287:2968-2972.

learning_objectives: Describe the relationship between AAA size and growth rate
Quantify annual rupture risk by diameter
Explain why the 5.5 cm threshold is used for intervention
Identify factors that increase rupture risk
Understand the lethality of ruptured AAA
common_errors: Using male thresholds for female patients
Not recognizing rapid expansion as indication for repair
clinical_pearls: Half of patients with ruptured AAA die before reaching the hospital
Women rupture at smaller diameters - consider 5.0 cm threshold
Rapid expansion (>1 cm/year) is an indication for repair regardless of size
The UK Small Aneurysm Trial proved surveillance is safe for <5.5 cm AAAs
